The date when Benioff made his initial controversial comments supporting Trump’s deployment of federal troops to San Francisco, which triggered public backlash and media scrutiny.

keyTakeAways: Marc Benioff, CEO of Salesforce, initially suggested that President Donald Trump should send the National Guard to San Francisco to address safety concerns, drawing significant criticism.

Benioff later retracted his comments, apologizing for causing concern and stating that after consulting local officials and attending the Dreamforce conference, he no longer believes the National Guard is needed.
The Dreamforce conference, which drew tens of thousands to San Francisco, was cited as a context for Benioff's initial caution in making the statement.
Benioff’s comments were part of a broader trend of tech billionaires in the Bay Area aligning with President Trump's policies, including support for federal troop deployment and increased ICE hiring.

Internal documents reportedly show Salesforce proposing AI tools to support Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) operations, including tip evaluation and investigations, raising ethical and civil rights concerns.
Venture capitalist Ron Conway resigned from the Salesforce Foundation board over Benioff’s Trump-related comments, signaling internal dissent and reputational damage.
Salesforce has a history of government contracts, including with ICE under both the Obama and Biden administrations, which has been cited in reporting as evidence of ongoing policy alignment.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Marc Benioff, CEO of Salesforce, initially suggested that President Donald Trump should deploy the National Guard to San Francisco to address safety concerns, sparking widespread criticism. After the Dreamforce conference, which drew tens of thousands to the city, Benioff retracted his comments and apologized, stating that local officials and the event’s safety demonstrated no need for federal troops. The controversy also revealed internal Salesforce documents indicating the company proposed AI tools to support ICE investigations, raising ethical and civil rights concerns. This alignment with Trump’s policies has drawn backlash, including from venture capitalist Ron Conway, who resigned from the Salesforce Foundation board. The incident reflects a broader trend of tech leaders in the Bay Area embracing conservative political stances, especially on law enforcement and immigration policy.
title: Marc Benioff Apologizes for Suggesting National Guard Be Sent to San Francisco
